Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of a woman (devotee?) or goddess. Her hair is parted in the middle and worn under a veil or sakkos. Mould-made and solid from a one-piece mould with a simple back. Poor detail. Traces of a light coating or wash/slip. Red-brown Nile silt fabric. Large head fragment, broken at neck.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A large and crude local copy of a standing or sitting woman figure of the Classical period, produced across the Greek world in Rhodes and Athens (GR 2008,5004.1, dated c. 460BC). A later production (i.e early Ptolemaic) cannot be excluded.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DC.019) (Phase 3)
